sectionTitle: K.5: Panchächär - The Five Codes of Conduct

tabs.caption: An introduction to the fivefold code of conduct in Jainism, forming the path to liberation (Moksha).

items.content: Panchächär, meaning 'five conducts', represents the practical observance of Jainism. It is a comprehensive framework guiding a soul towards liberation. As stated by Ächārya Umāsvāti in the Tattvārtha-sutra: 'Samyag Darshan, Samyag Jnän and Samyak Chäritra constitute the path of liberation.' While these are the three core jewels, Jainism expands this into a fivefold code by including two significant aspects of conduct: Austerities (Tap) and Vigor (Virya). These five codes are Jnänächär, Darshanächär, Chäriträchär, Tapächär, and Viryächär.

items.header: 1. Jnänächär - Code of Acquiring Right Knowledge
items.content: This code lays down the norms for acquiring right knowledge (Samyag Jnän). It involves understanding the five types of knowledge, from sensory perception to ultimate omniscience, and practicing the eightfold disciplines like studying at the proper time, showing reverence to teachers, and understanding the true meaning of scriptures. The goal is to overcome the knowledge-obscuring (Jnänävaraniya) karma.

items.header: 2. Darshanächär - Code of Gaining Right Faith
items.content: This code focuses on developing right faith or conviction (Samyag Darshan). It involves cultivating an unwavering belief in the principles of Jainism, free from doubt, expectation, or influence from other doctrines. The eight aspects of Darshanächär guide a person from initial belief to profound self-realization.

items.header: 3. Chäriträchär - Code of Acquiring Right Conduct
items.content: This is the code of right conduct (Samyak Chäritra), where knowledge and faith are put into practice. It involves living life in accordance with Jain principles. For monastics, this includes observing the five Samitis (carefulness) and three Guptis (restraints), collectively known as Ashta Pravachan Mätä. For laypeople, it involves observing the twelve vows (Vrat).

items.header: 4. Tapächär - Code of Acquiring Right Austerities
items.content: This code pertains to the practice of austerities (Tap). Austerities are physical and mental exercises designed to purify the soul and shed accumulated karmas (Nirjarä). Jainism outlines twelve types of austerities, divided into six external (Bähya) and six internal (Abhyantar), to aid in spiritual development.

items.header: 5. Viryächär - Code of Exercising Right Vigor
items.content: This code is about exercising one's physical, mental, and spiritual energy (Virya) appropriately and to its fullest potential towards the goal of liberation. It emphasizes avoiding laziness and negligence, and channeling all energy into observing the other four codes of conduct. It is the practice of conscious endeavor (Purushärth) to overcome karmic bondage.

tabs.caption: Explore the structure of knowledge (Jnän) in Jainism, from indirect sensory perception to direct, pure omniscience.

tabData.title: Jnänächär: The Hierarchy of Right Knowledge
tabData.description: This mind map illustrates the five types of knowledge and the key concepts related to acquiring it.

nodes.description: Code of Acquiring Right Knowledge. One of the five Panchächärs.
Indirect Knowledge, gained through the senses and mind. It is subject to destruction.
Direct Knowledge, which arises from spiritual development, independent of the senses.
Sensory Knowledge: Acquired through the five senses and the mind (intellect).
Scriptural Knowledge: Gained by listening, reading, and studying scriptures.
Clairvoyance: Extra-sensory knowledge of tangible things, limited by time and space.
Telepathy: Knowledge of the thoughts and mental processes of other five-sensed beings.
Omniscience: Pure, complete, and infinite knowledge of everything in the past, present, and future. Once attained, it is indestructible.
Knowledge-Obscuring Karma: The type of karma that prevents the soul from acquiring knowledge.
Self-Effort/Endeavor: The effort made to break the bondage of karma, essential for gaining knowledge.

tabs.caption: Delve into the codes for Right Faith (Darshanächär) and Right Conduct (Chäriträchär), the foundations of Jain practice.

items.header: Darshanächär - The Eightfold Code of Right Faith
items.content:
Right Faith (Samyag Darshan) is the bedrock of the spiritual journey. Darshanächär provides an eight-step guide to cultivate unshakable conviction. The eight aspects are:
  • Nissankia: Doubtlessness; staying above all doubts about Jain principles.
  • Nikkankhia: Desirelessness; absence of expectation for worldly gains in return for faith.
  • Nirvichikitsä: Unflinching faith; not being repulsed by the physical appearance or austerities of ascetics.
  • Amoodh-drashti: Non-delusion; not being influenced by the glamour of false faiths or gurus.
  • Uvavooha (Upaguhan): Adoration; praising the virtues of fellow Jains and concealing their shortcomings.
  • Sthirikaran: Stabilization; helping to stabilize the faith of others who may be wavering.
  • Vätsalya: Affection; showing selfless affection for coreligionists and spiritual aspirants.
  • Prabhävanä: Glorification; raising the esteem for Jainism through devotion, charity, and spiritual activities.

items.header: Chäriträchär - The Code of Right Conduct
items.content: Chäriträchär is the practical application of Right Knowledge and Right Faith. It is the code that governs behavior. The conduct prescribed for ascetics is absolute and mandatory, while for laypeople it is modified to accommodate worldly life. The core of monastic conduct is the Ashta Pravachan Mätä.

items.header: Ashta Pravachan Mätä - The Eight Mother-like Teachings
items.content:
This eightfold monastic code of conduct is as fundamental and caring as a mother's teachings. It consists of five Samitis and three Guptis.

The Five Samitis (Carefulness):
1. Iryä Samiti: Carefulness during physical movements to avoid harming any living being.
2. Bhäshä Samiti: Carefulness during verbal movements, speaking truthfully, beneficially, and only when necessary.
3. Eshanä Samiti: Carefulness while obtaining food and water, ensuring it is pure and obtained without causing harm.
4. Ädän Nikshep Samiti: Carefulness during placement of objects, inspecting objects and places before placing/taking them.
5. Utsarga Samiti: Carefulness in disposing of bodily wastes in a place free of living beings.

The Three Guptis (Restraints):
1. Mana Gupti: Restraining the mind from impure thoughts like anger, greed, and ego.
2. Vachan Gupti: Restraining speech, observing silence and controlling the urge to speak.
3. Käya Gupti: Restraining the body, controlling physical activities and maintaining a steady posture to avoid harm.

tabs.caption: Learn the twelve types of austerities (Tap) that help in purifying the soul and shedding karma.

tabData.title: Bähya Tap - External Austerities
tabData.description: These six austerities are primarily related to physical discipline and are visible to others.

cards.back: Fasting. Completely abstaining from food and water for a set period of time.
Eating less than one's normal diet or hunger.
Curtailing desires by taking a vow to accept food only if certain conditions are met.
Renouncing tasty and stimulating foods, such as milk, curd, ghee, oil, sugar, and fried foods. (e.g., Äyambil).
Voluntarily enduring bodily hardships and discomforts with equanimity.
Restraining the senses and occupying a minimum amount of space, staying in a secluded place.

tabData.title: Abhyantar Tap - Internal Austerities
tabData.description: These six austerities are primarily related to mental and spiritual discipline and are not visible externally.

cards.back: Repentance. Confessing and atoning for transgressions committed knowingly or unknowingly.
Modesty/Humility. Showing respect towards gurus and those who are spiritually advanced.
Selfless service to monks, nuns, fellow aspirants, and the needy without any expectation.
Study of self and religious scriptures to acquire right knowledge.
Meditation. Concentrating the mind on a single object, leading to spiritual purification.
Renunciation of attachment to the physical body, standing or sitting motionless for a period.

tabs.caption: Understand the importance of using one's energy correctly (Viryächär) and learn to identify the vices that hinder spiritual growth.

items.header: Viryächär - The Code of Right Vigor
items.content: Viryächär is the code of exercising one's energy (Virya) in the right manner for spiritual upliftment. It requires using one's mental, verbal, and physical capabilities to their fullest potential in observing the other codes of conduct (knowledge, faith, conduct, austerities). It is the antidote to laziness, negligence, and lethargy. As Bhagawän Mahävir stated, one should not be lazy for even a single moment on the journey towards liberation.

items.header: Purushärth vs. Prärabdha - Endeavor vs. Destiny
items.content: While Jainism believes in karma, it does not support passivity. Prärabdha (destiny) is the result of past karmas, but Purushärth (endeavor) is the conscious effort one makes in the present to overcome the effects of that karma. Viryächär is the essence of Purushärth, emphasizing that one should observe all spiritual codes with utmost vigor and determination, rather than being a helpless victim of past actions.

items.header: Five Vices (Pramäd) that Hinder Spiritual Growth
items.content:
Pramäd means negligence or spiritual laziness. To practice Viryächär, one must avoid these five major types of vices:

1. Vishay: Indulgence in the five sensuous pleasures (sound, sight, smell, taste, touch).
2. Kashäy: The four inner passions of Anger (Krodh), Ego (Män), Deceit (Mäyä), and Greed (Lobh).
3. Vikathä: Indulging in unnecessary or sinful talk, such as gossip about politics, food, or nation.
4. Nidrä: Excessive sleep or a state of non-alertness and lethargy.
5. Vyasan: Addiction to material objects or harmful habits like gambling and smoking.

questions.question: What are the five Ächärs that collectively form Panchächär?
options: Mati Jnän, Shrut Jnän, Avadhi Jnän, Manah-paryav Jnän, Keval Jnän

questions.question: According to the Tattvärtha-sutra, what three things constitute the path to liberation (Mokshamārgah)?
options: Right Faith, Right Knowledge, Right Conduct
Right Austerity, Right Vigor, Right Faith
Right Practice, Right Belief, Right Living
Right Mind, Right Speech, Right Action
questions.answer: Right Faith, Right Knowledge, Right Conduct
